articles.headline: What a Federal Reserve Rate Increase Means for You
articles.snippet: Rates on credit cards, savings accounts and different kinds of loans move when the Fed changes its benchmark rate. Here’s what you need to know.
articles.abstract: Rates on credit cards, savings accounts and different kinds of loans move when the Fed changes its benchmark rate. Here’s what you need to know.
articles.lead_paragraph: Consumers are already feeling squeezed by higher prices on daily necessities, whether it’s at the gas pump or in the supermarket. And now that interest rates are ticking higher, the cost of borrowing — from credit cards and car financing to private student loans — will increase, too.

articles.headline: U.S. Casts a Global Net to Stop Shipments to Russia
articles.snippet: To try to halt the war in Ukraine, the U.S. and its allies have imposed the most sweeping export controls seen in decades on Russia. Now they have to enforce them.
articles.abstract: To try to halt the war in Ukraine, the U.S. and its allies have imposed the most sweeping export controls seen in decades on Russia. Now they have to enforce them.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The United States, in partnership with its allies, has hit Russia with some of the most sweeping export restrictions ever imposed, barring companies across the world from sending advanced technology in order to penalize President Vladimir V. Putin for his invasion of Ukraine.

articles.headline: Russia’s Attack Rallies a Divided Nation: The United States
articles.snippet: Americans across the political spectrum express broad support for Ukraine, though opinions diverge on what that means and how far the U.S. response should go.
articles.abstract: Americans across the political spectrum express broad support for Ukraine, though opinions diverge on what that means and how far the U.S. response should go.
articles.lead_paragraph: After two years of political divisions and economic disruptions bolstered by an unending pandemic, many Americans say they are coming together around a common cause: support for Ukraine, a country under daily siege by Russian forces.
articles.byline: By Audra D. S. Burch, Jennifer Medina, Jazmine Ulloa and Maya King

articles.headline: Invoking America’s Darkest Days, Zelensky Pleads for More U.S. Aid
articles.snippet: President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine called for a no-fly zone and more weapons to combat Russia’s assault and implored President Biden to be “the leader of peace.”
articles.abstract: President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine called for a no-fly zone and more weapons to combat Russia’s assault and implored President Biden to be “the leader of peace.”
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine invoked the memory of America’s darkest days on Wednesday as he pleaded for more military aid to combat Russia’s “inhumane destruction” of his country, directly challenging President Biden and members of Congress to help by showing a wrenching video of the carnage in Ukraine’s cities.
articles.byline: By Catie Edmondson and Michael D. Shear

articles.headline: ‘Finish Them Off’: Aid Workers, Found on Battlefield, Executed by Soldiers
articles.snippet: Three employees of Doctors Without Borders set out to rescue the wounded in a war zone in northern Ethiopia. Their fate shows the treacherous path for many aid workers in conflict zones.
articles.abstract: Three employees of Doctors Without Borders set out to rescue the wounded in a war zone in northern Ethiopia. Their fate shows the treacherous path for many aid workers in conflict zones.
articles.lead_paragraph: This story was supported by the Pulitzer Center on Crisis Reporting.
articles.byline: By Simon Marks and Declan Walsh

articles.headline: Inflation vs. Recession: The Fed Is Walking a Tightrope
articles.snippet: American consumers already have high inflation. Because of the oil price shock and Russia’s war, the odds of a recession have increased, too.
articles.abstract: American consumers already have high inflation. Because of the oil price shock and Russia’s war, the odds of a recession have increased, too.
articles.lead_paragraph: Even before Russia invaded Ukraine, the Federal Reserve was in a tough spot.

articles.headline: Republicans Push Crackdown on Crime Wave That Doesn’t Exist: Voter Fraud
articles.snippet: Election fraud is exceedingly rare and often accidental. Still, G.O.P. lawmakers and prosecutors are promoting tough new enforcement efforts.
articles.abstract: Election fraud is exceedingly rare and often accidental. Still, G.O.P. lawmakers and prosecutors are promoting tough new enforcement efforts.
articles.lead_paragraph: The Florida Legislature last week created a law enforcement agency — informally called the election police — to tackle what Gov. Ron DeSantis and other Republicans have declared an urgent problem: the roughly 0.000677 percent of voters suspected of committing voter fraud.
articles.byline: By Reid J. Epstein and Nick Corasaniti
